question: Question_02_(a)
statement:
Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work.
Simplification of answers is not required.

Sketch the bounded region that lies between the curves $y = 2-x^{2}$ and
$y = |x|$, and show that the area of this region equals $\tfrac{7}{3}$.
sols:
A picture is included below.

First, find the points of intersection.

$2-x^{2} = |x|$

Take the positive values of $x$ first and solving gives

$0 = 2-x^{2} - |x| = -x^{2}-x + 2 = -(x-1)(x+2)$

and so $x  = 1$ is a solution here (notice that we discard $x = -2$
since we started with only the positive \emph{x} values first). Now,
taking the negative \emph{x} values gives

$0 = 2-x^{2} - |x| = -x^{2}+x + 2 = -(x+1)(x-2)$

and so $x = -1$ is the other solution. Now, we can draw the picture (see
below). The picture clearly shows that the upper function is
2-\emph{x}\textsuperscript{2}, and that the function $2-x^{2}-|x|$ is an
even function. So we see that it suffices to compute

$A = 2\int_{0}^{1}(2-x^{2}-|x|)\,dx = 2\int_{0}^{1}(2-x^{2}-x)\, dx$

Evaluating gives

\begin{align*}
A &= 2\int_{0}^{1}(2-x^{2}-x)\,dx \\
&= \left.2\left(2x - \frac{x^{3}}{3} - \frac{x^{2}}{2}\right)\right|_{0}^{1}\\
&= 2\left(2 - \frac{1}{3} - \frac{1}{2}\right)\\
&= 3 - \frac{2}{3}\\
&= \frac{7}{3}\end{align*}

as required.
